brain_structures.clinical_definition: Almond-shaped structure in the limbic system responsible for processing emotions, particularly fear and threat detection.
brain_structures.user_friendly: Your brain's alarm system that spots danger.
brain_structures.analogy: Like a smoke detector that can't tell the difference between burnt toast and a real fire - it reacts to anything that seems threatening.
brain_structures.why_it_matters: When your amygdala fires off, your body prepares to fight or run, even when there's no actual danger. This is why you might feel your heart race before giving a presentation.
brain_structures.example_sentence: When you feel your hands get sweaty before speaking in class, that's your amygdala treating the audience like a physical threat.

brain_structures.clinical_definition: The anterior part of the frontal lobes, responsible for executive functions including decision-making, planning, and emotional regulation.
brain_structures.user_friendly: Your brain's command center for making smart choices.
brain_structures.analogy: Like the CEO of your brain - it thinks ahead, weighs options, and keeps your emotions in check.
brain_structures.why_it_matters: This part of your brain helps you resist temptations and make long-term plans instead of acting on impulse. It's the last part to fully develop (around age 25).
brain_structures.example_sentence: When you want to eat dessert but choose the salad instead, that's your prefrontal cortex overriding your immediate desires.

brain_structures.clinical_definition: A seahorse-shaped structure in the medial temporal lobe crucial for memory formation and consolidation.
brain_structures.user_friendly: Your brain's filing cabinet for new memories.
brain_structures.analogy: Like a librarian who decides which books to keep and where to store them on the shelves.
brain_structures.why_it_matters: Without a working hippocampus, you couldn't form new long-term memories. Every day would feel brand new because you couldn't remember what happened yesterday.
brain_structures.example_sentence: When you study for a test and remember the facts later, your hippocampus transferred that information from short-term to long-term storage.

brain_structures.clinical_definition: A group of subcortical nuclei involved in motor control, procedural learning, and habit formation.
brain_structures.user_friendly: Your brain's habit tracker and autopilot system.
brain_structures.analogy: Like cruise control in a car - it runs practiced behaviors automatically so you don't have to think about them.
brain_structures.why_it_matters: This is why you can tie your shoes or ride a bike without thinking. It also explains why bad habits are so hard to break once they're programmed in.
brain_structures.example_sentence: When you automatically reach for your phone first thing in the morning, your basal ganglia have turned that into a habit loop.

brain_structures.clinical_definition: Brain region involved in error detection, conflict monitoring, and emotional regulation.
brain_structures.user_friendly: Your brain's error detector and conflict resolver.
brain_structures.analogy: Like a quality control inspector who spots mistakes and flags when two options are competing.
brain_structures.why_it_matters: This part lights up when you make a mistake or face a tough choice. It helps you learn from errors and adjust your behavior.
brain_structures.example_sentence: When you accidentally say the wrong word and immediately feel embarrassed, your anterior cingulate caught the error.

neurochemicals.clinical_definition: Neurotransmitter involved in reward processing, motivation, pleasure, and motor control.
neurochemicals.user_friendly: Your brain's reward chemical that makes you want things.
neurochemicals.analogy: Like getting a gold star sticker - it makes you feel good and want to do that activity again.
neurochemicals.why_it_matters: Dopamine drives your motivation and makes behaviors feel rewarding. Too much or too little can lead to addiction or depression.
neurochemicals.example_sentence: When you check social media and see likes on your post, you get a dopamine hit that makes you want to check again later.

neurochemicals.clinical_definition: Neurotransmitter that regulates mood, appetite, sleep, memory, and social behavior.
neurochemicals.user_friendly: Your brain's mood stabilizer and happiness helper.
neurochemicals.analogy: Like a thermostat that keeps your emotional temperature balanced - not too high, not too low.
neurochemicals.why_it_matters: Low serotonin is linked to depression and anxiety. Many antidepressants work by increasing serotonin levels in your brain.
neurochemicals.example_sentence: When you feel content and relaxed after exercise or sunshine, that's partly from increased serotonin.

neurochemicals.clinical_definition: Stress hormone released by the adrenal glands that increases blood sugar and aids metabolism.
neurochemicals.analogy: Like an emergency broadcast system that floods your body with energy when trouble seems near.
neurochemicals.why_it_matters: Short bursts of cortisol help you handle stress, but constant high levels damage your health, memory, and immune system.
neurochemicals.example_sentence: When you're stuck in traffic and feel tense and jittery, cortisol is preparing your body for action even though you can't actually do anything.

neurochemicals.clinical_definition: Neuropeptide hormone involved in social bonding, trust, empathy, and childbirth.
neurochemicals.user_friendly: Your brain's bonding and trust chemical.
neurochemicals.analogy: Like emotional glue that makes you feel connected to people you care about.
neurochemicals.why_it_matters: Oxytocin helps form close relationships and makes social connections feel rewarding. It's released during hugs, touch, and positive social interactions.
neurochemicals.example_sentence: When you hug a friend and feel warm and connected, oxytocin is strengthening your bond.

neurochemicals.clinical_definition: Neurotransmitter and hormone that increases alertness, arousal, and attention.
neurochemicals.user_friendly: Your brain's wake-up and focus chemical.
neurochemicals.analogy: Like hitting the gas pedal - it revs up your brain and body for action.
neurochemicals.why_it_matters: This chemical makes you alert and focused during stress or excitement. Too much can cause anxiety; too little can cause fatigue.
neurochemicals.example_sentence: When you hear a loud noise and suddenly feel wide awake and focused, norepinephrine just flooded your system.

neural_processes.clinical_definition: The brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections throughout life.
neural_processes.user_friendly: Your brain's ability to rewire itself.
neural_processes.analogy: Like a city that can build new roads and close old ones based on traffic patterns.
neural_processes.why_it_matters: This means your brain can change at any age. You can break old habits, learn new skills, and recover from injuries by creating new neural pathways.
neural_processes.example_sentence: When you practice guitar every day and it gradually gets easier, that's neuroplasticity strengthening the connections you need.

neural_processes.clinical_definition: Networks of interconnected neurons that transmit information, strengthened through repeated activation.
neural_processes.analogy: Like trails in a forest - the more you walk the same path, the clearer and easier to follow it becomes.
neural_processes.why_it_matters: Repeated thoughts and actions create stronger pathways, making behaviors automatic. This is why practice works and why changing habits is hard.
neural_processes.example_sentence: When you always think 'I can't do this' in tough situations, you're strengthening a negative thought pathway.

neural_processes.clinical_definition: Process of eliminating weak or unused neural connections while strengthening frequently used ones.
neural_processes.user_friendly: Your brain's cleanup crew that removes unused connections.
neural_processes.analogy: Like a gardener trimming dead branches so the healthy ones can grow stronger.
neural_processes.why_it_matters: This helps your brain become more efficient by eliminating connections you don't use. It's most active during childhood and teenage years.
neural_processes.example_sentence: When you stop practicing a language and gradually forget it, synaptic pruning is removing those unused connections.

neural_processes.clinical_definition: Persistent strengthening of synapses based on recent patterns of activity, underlying learning and memory.
neural_processes.user_friendly: How practice makes your brain connections permanent.
neural_processes.analogy: Like wearing a path in the grass - each time you walk it, the path gets more defined and easier to follow.
neural_processes.why_it_matters: This is the cellular basis of learning and memory. Repeated activation of neurons together makes them wire together permanently.
neural_processes.example_sentence: When you practice your multiplication tables until you know them by heart, long-term potentiation has made those connections strong.

neural_processes.clinical_definition: Formation of myelin sheath around nerve fibers, increasing the speed of neural signal transmission.
neural_processes.user_friendly: Insulation that makes brain signals travel faster.
neural_processes.analogy: Like upgrading from dirt roads to paved highways - information moves much quicker.
neural_processes.why_it_matters: More myelin means faster thinking and better coordination. It continues developing into your 20s, which is why teenagers sometimes make impulsive decisions.
neural_processes.example_sentence: When a toddler gradually learns to walk smoothly, increasing myelination is speeding up the signals between their brain and muscles.

cognitive_processes.clinical_definition: Mental discomfort experienced when holding contradictory beliefs, values, or attitudes simultaneously.
cognitive_processes.user_friendly: The uncomfortable feeling when your beliefs clash.
cognitive_processes.analogy: Like trying to hold two magnets together that repel each other - it creates tension.
cognitive_processes.why_it_matters: Your brain hates inconsistency, so you'll often change your beliefs or justify your actions to reduce this discomfort.
cognitive_processes.example_sentence: When you value health but eat junk food, the uncomfortable feeling you get is cognitive dissonance pushing you to either change your diet or rationalize your choices.

cognitive_processes.clinical_definition: Limited-capacity system for temporarily holding and manipulating information for complex cognitive tasks.
cognitive_processes.user_friendly: Your brain's short-term sticky note system.
cognitive_processes.analogy: Like juggling - you can only keep a few balls in the air at once before you drop them.
cognitive_processes.why_it_matters: Most people can hold about 4-7 pieces of information in working memory at once. When you forget why you walked into a room, your working memory was overloaded.
cognitive_processes.example_sentence: When you're doing math in your head and can only handle a few numbers before you lose track, that's your working memory limit.

cognitive_processes.clinical_definition: Set of mental skills including planning, focus, instruction following, and emotional control.
cognitive_processes.analogy: Like a coach who helps you plan plays, stay focused on the game, and control your emotions when things get tough.
cognitive_processes.why_it_matters: Strong executive function helps you succeed in school, work, and relationships. It lets you resist distractions and stick to long-term goals.
cognitive_processes.example_sentence: When you have a big project due and successfully break it into steps, schedule your time, and ignore social media to finish it, that's executive function at work.

cognitive_processes.clinical_definition: Tendency to pay more attention to emotionally salient stimuli while ignoring others.
cognitive_processes.user_friendly: Your brain's habit of focusing on certain things.
cognitive_processes.analogy: Like wearing glasses with a colored lens - everything looks tinted, and you notice some colors more than others.
cognitive_processes.why_it_matters: If you're anxious, you'll spot threats everywhere. If you're depressed, you'll notice negative things more. This keeps those feelings going.
cognitive_processes.example_sentence: When you're worried about failing a test, you notice every difficult question but miss the easy ones - that's attentional bias.

cognitive_processes.clinical_definition: Tendency to search for, interpret, and recall information that confirms pre-existing beliefs.
cognitive_processes.user_friendly: Seeing only what you already believe.
cognitive_processes.analogy: Like a detective who only collects evidence that supports their original suspect and ignores everything else.
cognitive_processes.why_it_matters: This bias makes it hard to change your mind even when you're wrong. You unconsciously filter out information that contradicts what you believe.
cognitive_processes.example_sentence: When you believe someone doesn't like you, you notice every time they don't smile at you but ignore the times they're friendly.

emotional_regulation.clinical_definition: Inability to manage emotional responses effectively, characterized by intense, prolonged reactions.
emotional_regulation.user_friendly: When your emotions get too big to control.
emotional_regulation.analogy: Like a volume knob stuck on maximum - everything feels too loud and you can't turn it down.
emotional_regulation.why_it_matters: People with emotional dysregulation struggle to calm down after getting upset. Learning regulation skills is crucial for mental health and relationships.
emotional_regulation.example_sentence: When a small criticism ruins your whole day and you can't stop feeling hurt, that's emotional dysregulation.

emotional_regulation.clinical_definition: Set of brain structures including amygdala and hippocampus involved in emotion, motivation, and behavior.
emotional_regulation.analogy: Like the engine room of your emotions - where feelings are generated and processed.
emotional_regulation.why_it_matters: This ancient part of your brain reacts faster than your thinking brain, which is why you feel before you think.
emotional_regulation.example_sentence: When you react emotionally to something before you can think it through, your limbic system acted first.

emotional_regulation.clinical_definition: Physiological and psychological reaction to perceived threats, activating fight-or-flight mechanisms.
emotional_regulation.analogy: Like pulling a fire alarm - it triggers a whole building to respond, whether there's a real fire or just burnt popcorn.
emotional_regulation.why_it_matters: Your body can't tell the difference between a real threat and a stressful situation, so it reacts the same way to both.
emotional_regulation.example_sentence: When you have a deadline and feel your heart racing and palms sweating, your stress response is preparing you to fight or run from danger that doesn't actually exist.

emotional_regulation.clinical_definition: Sense of the internal state of the body, including awareness of heartbeat, breathing, and hunger.
emotional_regulation.user_friendly: Your ability to sense what's happening inside your body.
emotional_regulation.analogy: Like having internal sensors that tell you when you're hungry, tired, stressed, or need to use the bathroom.
emotional_regulation.why_it_matters: Good interoception helps you understand your emotions and physical needs. Poor interoception can make it hard to know what you're feeling.
emotional_regulation.example_sentence: When you realize you're angry because you notice your jaw is clenched and your breathing is shallow, that's interoception helping you identify your emotion.

emotional_regulation.clinical_definition: Repetitive, passive focus on negative emotions and their causes without engaging in problem-solving.
emotional_regulation.user_friendly: Replaying the same negative thoughts over and over.
emotional_regulation.analogy: Like a hamster wheel for your mind - lots of mental activity but you're not getting anywhere.
emotional_regulation.why_it_matters: Rumination makes depression and anxiety worse. It feels like you're solving a problem, but you're actually just reinforcing negative patterns.
emotional_regulation.example_sentence: When you lie awake at night replaying an embarrassing moment from three years ago, that's rumination keeping you stuck.

behavioral_psychology.clinical_definition: Learning process where behavior is modified by consequences (reinforcement or punishment).
behavioral_psychology.analogy: Like training a dog - behaviors that get treats happen more often, behaviors that get scolded happen less.
behavioral_psychology.why_it_matters: Most of your daily behaviors were shaped this way. Understanding this helps you recognize what's reinforcing your habits.
behavioral_psychology.example_sentence: When you get compliments for working hard and start working harder, that's operant conditioning shaping your behavior.

behavioral_psychology.clinical_definition: Any consequence that strengthens or increases the likelihood of a behavior recurring.
behavioral_psychology.user_friendly: Anything that makes you do something more often.
behavioral_psychology.analogy: Like getting paid for a job - it makes you want to keep doing the work.
behavioral_psychology.why_it_matters: Reinforcement is more powerful than punishment for changing behavior. Even small rewards can create lasting habits.
behavioral_psychology.example_sentence: When your phone buzzes with a notification and you feel excited to check it, that excitement reinforces your phone-checking habit.

behavioral_psychology.clinical_definition: Gradual weakening and disappearance of a learned behavior when reinforcement is no longer provided.
behavioral_psychology.user_friendly: How behaviors fade when they stop paying off.
behavioral_psychology.analogy: Like a plant that dies without water - behaviors die out without reinforcement.
behavioral_psychology.why_it_matters: This is how you break habits. Stop reinforcing the behavior and it will gradually disappear, though it may temporarily spike first.
behavioral_psychology.example_sentence: When you stop responding to someone's attention-seeking behavior and they eventually stop doing it, that's extinction.

behavioral_psychology.clinical_definition: Condition where repeated uncontrollable stressors lead to passive acceptance and failure to escape.
behavioral_psychology.user_friendly: Giving up because you learned nothing you do matters.
behavioral_psychology.analogy: Like a dog that stops trying to avoid shocks after learning there's no escape, even when escape becomes possible.
behavioral_psychology.why_it_matters: This explains why people stay in bad situations - they've learned that trying doesn't help. Breaking this pattern requires proving that actions can make a difference.
behavioral_psychology.example_sentence: When you've failed at dieting so many times that you don't even try anymore, that's learned helplessness.

behavioral_psychology.clinical_definition: Reinforcement schedule where behavior is rewarded only some of the time.
behavioral_psychology.user_friendly: Sometimes getting rewarded, not every time.
behavioral_psychology.analogy: Like slot machines - you don't win every pull, which makes you pull more often.
behavioral_psychology.why_it_matters: This creates the strongest, most persistent habits. It's why gambling is addictive and why variable rewards are so powerful.
behavioral_psychology.example_sentence: When you check your phone constantly because sometimes you get an exciting message, intermittent reinforcement is driving that behavior.

trauma_stress.clinical_definition: Physiological reaction to perceived harmful events, activating sympathetic nervous system for defensive action.
trauma_stress.analogy: Like an emergency evacuation system - it prepares you to either face danger or run away.
trauma_stress.why_it_matters: This ancient response saved our ancestors from predators, but now it activates for non-physical threats like presentations or conflicts.
trauma_stress.example_sentence: When you feel your heart pounding and muscles tensing before a confrontation, your fight-or-flight response is preparing you for physical combat.

trauma_stress.clinical_definition: Involuntary immobility response to overwhelming threat when fight or flight are not viable.
trauma_stress.user_friendly: When you get stuck and can't move during fear.
trauma_stress.analogy: Like a deer in headlights - your body shuts down because fighting or running won't work.
trauma_stress.why_it_matters: Many trauma survivors experience freeze responses. Understanding this helps people realize that freezing doesn't mean weakness or consent.
trauma_stress.example_sentence: When you blank out during a test even though you studied, that's a freeze response to the stress.

trauma_stress.clinical_definition: State of increased alertness and constant scanning for threats in the environment.
trauma_stress.user_friendly: Being on high alert all the time.
trauma_stress.analogy: Like a security guard who never takes a break - constantly watching for danger even when it's safe.
trauma_stress.why_it_matters: Common after trauma, hypervigilance is exhausting and prevents relaxation. It keeps your stress response constantly activated.
trauma_stress.example_sentence: When you can't relax at a party because you're always watching the door and monitoring people's reactions, that's hypervigilance.

trauma_stress.clinical_definition: Disconnection between thoughts, memories, feelings, actions, or sense of identity.
trauma_stress.user_friendly: Mentally checking out when things get overwhelming.
trauma_stress.analogy: Like your mind leaving your body - you're physically present but mentally somewhere else.
trauma_stress.why_it_matters: Dissociation is a defense mechanism during trauma. Understanding it helps people recognize they're not 'going crazy' when it happens.
trauma_stress.example_sentence: When you drive home and don't remember the trip because you were on autopilot, that's mild dissociation.

trauma_stress.clinical_definition: Optimal arousal zone where the nervous system can function effectively and regulate emotions.
trauma_stress.user_friendly: Your sweet spot for handling stress.
trauma_stress.analogy: Like Goldilocks - not too activated (anxious) or too shut down (numb), but just right for functioning well.
trauma_stress.why_it_matters: When you're outside your window, you can't think clearly or regulate emotions. Learning to stay within it is key to emotional stability.
trauma_stress.example_sentence: When you're calm enough to focus but alert enough to care, you're in your window of tolerance.

addiction_reward.clinical_definition: Neural circuit primarily involving ventral tegmental area and nucleus accumbens that processes pleasure and reinforcement.
addiction_reward.user_friendly: The brain circuit that makes things feel good.
addiction_reward.analogy: Like a reward center in a video game - it lights up when you do something your brain thinks is beneficial.
addiction_reward.why_it_matters: This pathway evolved to reward survival behaviors like eating and sex, but it also responds to drugs, social media, and other potentially addictive things.
addiction_reward.example_sentence: When you eat chocolate and feel pleasure, your reward pathway is releasing dopamine to make you want to eat it again.

addiction_reward.clinical_definition: Decreased response to a drug or behavior over time, requiring increased amounts for the same effect.
addiction_reward.user_friendly: Needing more to get the same feeling.
addiction_reward.analogy: Like turning up the volume because the same level doesn't sound loud enough anymore.
addiction_reward.why_it_matters: Tolerance drives escalating use in addiction. What started as one drink becomes three because your brain adapted to the lower dose.
addiction_reward.example_sentence: When you need two cups of coffee to feel awake when one used to work, that's tolerance.

addiction_reward.clinical_definition: Intense desire or urge to engage in a behavior or consume a substance.
addiction_reward.user_friendly: A powerful want that's hard to ignore.
addiction_reward.analogy: Like an itch you desperately want to scratch - it keeps demanding your attention until you give in.
addiction_reward.why_it_matters: Cravings are triggered by cues in your environment and can be incredibly strong. Understanding their temporary nature helps you resist them.
addiction_reward.example_sentence: When you smell cookies baking and suddenly must have one, even though you weren't hungry, that's a craving.

addiction_reward.clinical_definition: Rapid increase in dopamine levels in response to rewarding stimuli.
addiction_reward.user_friendly: A sudden burst of feel-good brain chemicals.
addiction_reward.analogy: Like a sugar rush for your brain - a quick hit of pleasure that fades fast.
addiction_reward.why_it_matters: Your brain learns to crave these spikes, which is why addictive things are often those that cause big, fast dopamine increases.
addiction_reward.example_sentence: When you check your phone and see a text from your crush, the excited feeling is from a dopamine spike.

addiction_reward.clinical_definition: Return to substance use or problematic behavior after a period of abstinence or improvement.
addiction_reward.user_friendly: Falling back into an old habit you'd quit.
addiction_reward.analogy: Like taking a detour back to your old route when you were trying to go a new way.
addiction_reward.why_it_matters: Relapse is a normal part of recovery, not a failure. Understanding triggers and having a plan helps prevent it.
addiction_reward.example_sentence: When you quit biting your nails for two weeks but start again after a stressful day, that's a relapse.
